column1: Seasonal Indexes Used to Adjust Housing Units Sold and For Sale
1The implicit seasonal index is the ratio of the unadjusted number of houses sold in the United
States to the seasonally adjusted number of houses sold in the United States, (i.e., to the sum of
the seasonally adjusted values for the four regions).
2Beginning in January 2007, the seasonal index is implicitly derived as the ratio of the seasonal
index for New Houses for Sale to the implicit seasonal index for U.S. Houses Sold.  Prior to
January 2007, the seasonal index was explicitly derived.
Note:  These seasonal indexes include trading-day adjustment factors.
